items.title: Millions of Britons face higher risk of heart failure due to dirty air, study suggests
items.standfirst: Exclusive: stroke risk is 7% higher and heart failure risk increases by 27% in areas with worst level of pollution, research showsMillions of Britons face a higher risk of stroke or heart failure because of dirty air where they live.People living in areas of the UK with the worst levels of air pollution are 27% more likely to develop heart failure, compared with people in areas with the cleanest air, a study suggests. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Impact of chatbots on mental health is warning over future of AI, expert says
clusters.neutral_headline: Chatbots and mental health: AI's unintended consequences

items.title: Impact of chatbots on mental health is warning over future of AI, expert says
items.standfirst: Nate Soares says case of US teenager Adam Raine highlights danger of unintended consequences in super-intelligent AIThe unforeseen impact of chatbots on mental health should be viewed as a warning over the existential threat posed by super-intelligent artificial intelligence systems, according to a prominent voice in AI safety.Nate Soares, a co-author of a new book on highly advanced AI titled If Anyone Builds It, Everyone Dies, said the example of Adam Raine, a US teenager who killed himself after months of conversations with the ChatGPT chatbot, underlined fundamental problems with controlling the technology. Continue reading...
items.content: Nate Soares says case of US teenager Adam Raine highlights danger of unintended consequences in super-intelligent AIThe unforeseen impact of chatbots on mental health should be viewed as a warning over the existential threat posed by super-intelligent artificial intelligence systems, according to a prominent voice in AI safety.Nate Soares, a co-author of a new book on highly advanced AI titled If Anyone Builds It, Everyone Dies, said the example of Adam Raine, a US teenager who killed himself after months of conversations with the ChatGPT chatbot, underlined fundamental problems with controlling the technology. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Chatbots' impact on mental health raises AI concerns.
The case of Adam Raine highlights AI's dangers.
Nate Soares discusses the unintended consequences of AI.
Soares is a co-author of a book on advanced AI.
The book's title is "If Anyone Builds It, Everyone Dies".

clusters.title: Australia is about to get a centre for disease control. How will it tackle public health challenges? | Allen Cheng for the Conversation
clusters.neutral_headline: Australia to establish a center for disease control

items.title: Australia is about to get a centre for disease control. How will it tackle public health challenges? | Allen Cheng for the Conversation
items.standfirst: Immediate issues for the agency will include bird flu, immunisation and misinformation, as well as the challenges of cancer, diabetes and heart disease. But there’s a lot we don’t know yet – and can we ensure it’s apolitical?Australia is a step closer to having its own national agency to inform and coordinate public health responses – a permanent Australian Centre for Disease Control.Long-awaited draft legislation was tabled in parliament last week to create this permanent CDC, which is to start from 1 January 2026.1987Epidemiologist Prof Bob Douglas asks in the Medical Journal of Australia Does Australia need a centre for disease control? Continue reading...
items.content: Immediate issues for the agency will include bird flu, immunisation and misinformation, as well as the challenges of cancer, diabetes and heart disease. But there’s a lot we don’t know yet – and can we ensure it’s apolitical?Australia is a step closer to having its own national agency to inform and coordinate public health responses – a permanent Australian Centre for Disease Control.Long-awaited draft legislation was tabled in parliament last week to create this permanent CDC, which is to start from 1 January 2026.1987Epidemiologist Prof Bob Douglas asks in the Medical Journal of Australia Does Australia need a centre for disease control? Continue reading...

ai_summary: Australia is creating a national agency for disease control.
The agency will coordinate public health responses.
The CDC will start operations on January 1, 2026.
Immediate issues include bird flu and misinformation.
The agency will address challenges like cancer and diabetes.

clusters.title: Drug to prevent heart attacks is not ‘better than aspirin’ for everyone | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Drug to prevent heart attacks is not ‘better than aspirin’ for everyone | Letters: For people with lower levels of the enzyme required to metabolise clopidogrel, aspirin remains the better option – a personalised approach is required, write Dr Ronnie Ramlogan, Dr Dimitri Gagliardi, Dr Luigi Venetucci, Dr Abisope Akintola, Dr Cinzia Dello Russo and Prof Sir Munir Pirmohamed

items.title: Drug to prevent heart attacks is not ‘better than aspirin’ for everyone | Letters
items.standfirst: For people with lower levels of the enzyme required to metabolise clopidogrel, aspirin remains the better option – a personalised approach is required, write Dr Ronnie Ramlogan, Dr Dimitri Gagliardi, Dr Luigi Venetucci, Dr Abisope Akintola, Dr Cinzia Dello Russo and Prof Sir Munir PirmohamedYour article (Doctors find drug that is better than aspirin at preventing heart attacks, 31 August) is of great interest. It cites a study that proposes replacing aspirin, the cornerstone of antiplatelet therapy for individuals at high risk of heart attacks and strokes, with clopidogrel. We must point out, however, that clopidogrel does not work uniformly across individuals. Although mentioned in the Lancet publication, it was only lightly considered in the Guardian article.Clopidogrel is a prodrug. To work, it needs to be metabolised by a liver enzyme that varies in the population because of variations in the CYP2C19 gene. Most individuals have “normal” or “supra-normal” levels of the enzyme and clopidogrel works as expected. However, “intermediate metabolisers” activate clopidogrel less efficiently and “poor metabolisers” struggle to activate clopidogrel at all. For these people, clopidogrel may not provide enough protection against heart attacks or strokes. Continue reading...
items.content: For people with lower levels of the enzyme required to metabolise clopidogrel, aspirin remains the better option – a personalised approach is required, write Dr Ronnie Ramlogan, Dr Dimitri Gagliardi, Dr Luigi Venetucci, Dr Abisope Akintola, Dr Cinzia Dello Russo and Prof Sir Munir PirmohamedYour article (Doctors find drug that is better than aspirin at preventing heart attacks, 31 August) is of great interest. It cites a study that proposes replacing aspirin, the cornerstone of antiplatelet therapy for individuals at high risk of heart attacks and strokes, with clopidogrel. We must point out, however, that clopidogrel does not work uniformly across individuals. Although mentioned in the Lancet publication, it was only lightly considered in the Guardian article.Clopidogrel is a prodrug. To work, it needs to be metabolised by a liver enzyme that varies in the population because of variations in the CYP2C19 gene. Most individuals have “normal” or “supra-normal” levels of the enzyme and clopidogrel works as expected. However, “intermediate metabolisers” activate clopidogrel less efficiently and “poor metabolisers” struggle to activate clopidogrel at all. For these people, clopidogrel may not provide enough protection against heart attacks or strokes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Clopidogrel's effectiveness varies among individuals.
Aspirin may be better for those with low enzyme levels.
Clopidogrel requires a liver enzyme for activation.
"Intermediate metabolisers" may not fully activate clopidogrel.
"Poor metabolisers" may not benefit from clopidogrel.

clusters.title: Don’t leave social care out of the equation | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Social care must be included in healthcare reform

items.title: Don’t leave social care out of the equation | Letters
items.standfirst: Reform of the community-based care sector is long overdue, says Kathryn MarsdenThe NHS’s year-round hospital overcrowding is not the product of a single failing, but the result of two interdependent systems under pressure: health and social care (NHS corridor care now year-round crisis in England, experts say, 1 September). The government’s ambition to build an “NHS fit for the future” through prevention, neighbourhood services and digital tools is welcome, but this vision risks treating symptoms rather than causes if social care is left out of the equation.Unless there is sufficient capacity in community-based social care to support people recovering at home, the logjam will persist, and “corridor care” will remain a reality. The evidence is clear: timely investment in community services such as reablement and intermediate care prevents unnecessary admissions, speeds up safe discharges, and delivers strong returns on investment for the NHS. Continue reading...
items.content: Reform of the community-based care sector is long overdue, says Kathryn MarsdenThe NHS’s year-round hospital overcrowding is not the product of a single failing, but the result of two interdependent systems under pressure: health and social care (NHS corridor care now year-round crisis in England, experts say, 1 September). The government’s ambition to build an “NHS fit for the future” through prevention, neighbourhood services and digital tools is welcome, but this vision risks treating symptoms rather than causes if social care is left out of the equation.Unless there is sufficient capacity in community-based social care to support people recovering at home, the logjam will persist, and “corridor care” will remain a reality. The evidence is clear: timely investment in community services such as reablement and intermediate care prevents unnecessary admissions, speeds up safe discharges, and delivers strong returns on investment for the NHS. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Social care reform is long overdue, according to letters.
NHS overcrowding results from health and social care pressures.
The government's vision risks treating symptoms, not causes.
Investment in community services prevents unnecessary admissions.
Timely investment delivers strong returns for the NHS.

clusters.title: Women in UK with polycystic ovarian syndrome facing widespread failures in treatment, report finds
clusters.neutral_headline: PCOS treatment faces widespread failures in UK

items.title: Women in UK with polycystic ovarian syndrome facing widespread failures in treatment, report finds
items.standfirst: Long delays in diagnosis and limited access to treatment among issues faced by women with condition that affects about one in eight womenWomen living with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) face prolonged delays in diagnosis and limited access to treatment, according to a report by a parliamentary group.More than a third of women with the condition had to wait longer than four years for a PCOS diagnosis, according to the report, and after diagnosis almost two-fifths (38%) of respondents were not provided with any resources. Continue reading...
items.content: Long delays in diagnosis and limited access to treatment among issues faced by women with condition that affects about one in eight womenWomen living with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) face prolonged delays in diagnosis and limited access to treatment, according to a report by a parliamentary group.More than a third of women with the condition had to wait longer than four years for a PCOS diagnosis, according to the report, and after diagnosis almost two-fifths (38%) of respondents were not provided with any resources. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Women with PCOS face delays in diagnosis and treatment.
Over a third waited over four years for diagnosis.
Almost 40% received no resources after diagnosis.
The report highlights issues faced by women with PCOS.
The report was conducted by a parliamentary group.

clusters.title: The kindness of strangers: a nurse saw me crying and asked if I wanted a hug
clusters.neutral_headline: Nurse's hug provided comfort during cancer treatment

items.title: The kindness of strangers: a nurse saw me crying and asked if I wanted a hug
items.standfirst: I had cancer and I was alone in hospital when it all suddenly hit me. I have never needed a hug more in my lifeRead more in the Kindness of strangers seriesIn 2024, I was unexpectedly diagnosed with leukaemia. I was 34. I had no symptoms (none!) and it came at the worst possible time, although there is never a good time.I am a musician and was one week away from flying to New Zealand to be in a show. I was extremely excited about the show and, to be organised, I thought I’d get a blood test to check my iron levels before I left the country for five weeks. Continue reading...
items.content: I had cancer and I was alone in hospital when it all suddenly hit me. I have never needed a hug more in my lifeRead more in the Kindness of strangers seriesIn 2024, I was unexpectedly diagnosed with leukaemia. I was 34. I had no symptoms (none!) and it came at the worst possible time, although there is never a good time.I am a musician and was one week away from flying to New Zealand to be in a show. I was extremely excited about the show and, to be organised, I thought I’d get a blood test to check my iron levels before I left the country for five weeks. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A nurse offered a hug to a patient in the hospital.
The patient was alone and experiencing emotional distress.
The patient was diagnosed with leukemia at age 34.
The diagnosis came at an unexpected time for the patient.
The patient was a musician preparing for a show.

items.standfirst: Russian leader’s claim that people can ‘get younger’ through repeated organ transplants has raised eyebrowsPerhaps it was the extravagant display of deadly weaponry that prompted Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin to mull on mortality at this week’s military parade in Beijing.It was more banter than serious discussion, but with both aged 72, the Chinese president and his Russian counterpart may feel the cold hand on the shoulder more than Kim Jong-un, the 41-year-old North Korean leader who strolled beside them. clusters.title: Private menopause tests risk undermining NHS care, doctors say
clusters.neutral_headline: Private menopause tests risk undermining NHS care

items.title: Private menopause tests risk undermining NHS care, doctors say
items.standfirst: Expert says self-testing kits are clinically useless and can be a distraction from evidence-based treatmentExpensive, over-the-counter hormone tests for menopause are clinically useless and risk undermining women’s healthcare, senior doctors have warned.The testing kits, offered by private clinics and available to buy for self-testing, claim to offer tailored insights through measuring hormone levels. But they have been described by experts as misleading and medically unnecessary. Continue reading...
items.content: Expert says self-testing kits are clinically useless and can be a distraction from evidence-based treatmentExpensive, over-the-counter hormone tests for menopause are clinically useless and risk undermining women’s healthcare, senior doctors have warned.The testing kits, offered by private clinics and available to buy for self-testing, claim to offer tailored insights through measuring hormone levels. But they have been described by experts as misleading and medically unnecessary. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Trump’s former surgeon general urges president to fire RFK Jr
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump’s former surgeon general urges president to fire RFK Jr

items.title: Trump’s former surgeon general urges president to fire RFK Jr
items.standfirst: Jerome Adams cites vaccine policy and chaos at CDC and joins other officials in saying Kennedy is risking US healthThe surgeon general from the first Trump administration on Saturday said that the US president should “absolutely” fire health secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr over his “dangerous” policies on vaccines and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).Jerome Adams, who has become a pointed critic of the public health decisions being swiftly rolled out in the second Trump administration, made his most fierce attack yet on what has been unfolding. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: ‘I still want to achieve’: people living with stage 4 cancer embrace Chris Hoy charity ride
clusters.neutral_headline: People with Stage 4 Cancer Participate in Charity Cycling Event

items.title: ‘I still want to achieve’: people living with stage 4 cancer embrace Chris Hoy charity ride
items.standfirst: Inaugural Tour de 4 is tailored to individuals’ physical abilities and aims to challenge assumptions about stage 4 cancerMel Erwin is pragmatic about what it took to get her on a bike. “I have one and a half lungs. I’m on a treatment drug. I don’t identify as sporty. I wouldn’t have done it without a goal.”This Sunday the 57-year-old will roar up the Campsie Hills north of Glasgow in a “camp as Christmas” sparkly cape alongside her partner, Sarah, and 3,000 other participants. Continue reading...

I’m on a treatment drug. I don’t identify as sporty. I wouldn’t have done it without a goal.”This Sunday the 57-year-old will roar up the Campsie Hills north of Glasgow in a “camp as Christmas” sparkly cape alongside her partner, Sarah, and 3,000 other participants. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Inaugural Tour de 4 event is designed for individuals with varying physical abilities, including those with stage 4 cancer.
Mel Erwin, 57, will participate in the event despite having one and a half lungs and being on treatment.
Erwin states she would not have participated without a specific goal to achieve.
The event will take place in the Campsie Hills north of Glasgow this Sunday.
Approximately 3,000 participants, including Erwin and her partner, will be involved in the ride.

clusters.title: Climate crisis will increase frequency of lightning-sparked wildfires, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Climate Crisis Increases Lightning-Sparked Wildfire Frequency

items.title: Climate crisis will increase frequency of lightning-sparked wildfires, study finds
items.standfirst: These wildfires tend to burn in more remote areas and grow larger faster, posing a higher risk to public safety and healthThe climate crisis will continue making lightning-sparked wildfires more frequent for decades to come, which could produce cascading effects and worsen public safety and public health, experts and new research suggest.Lightning-caused fires tend to burn in more remote areas and therefore usually grow into larger fires than human-caused fires. That means a trend toward more lightning-caused fires is also probably making wildfires more deadly by producing more wildfire smoke and helping to drive a surge in air quality issues from coast to coast, especially over the past several years. Continue reading...
items.content: These wildfires tend to burn in more remote areas and grow larger faster, posing a higher risk to public safety and healthThe climate crisis will continue making lightning-sparked wildfires more frequent for decades to come, which could produce cascading effects and worsen public safety and public health, experts and new research suggest.Lightning-caused fires tend to burn in more remote areas and therefore usually grow into larger fires than human-caused fires. That means a trend toward more lightning-caused fires is also probably making wildfires more deadly by producing more wildfire smoke and helping to drive a surge in air quality issues from coast to coast, especially over the past several years. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Climate change will increase lightning-sparked wildfires for decades, according to new research.
Lightning-caused wildfires often occur in remote areas, growing larger and faster than human-caused fires.
Increased lightning-caused fires may worsen public safety and health due to more smoke.
Wildfire smoke contributes to air quality issues across the country, especially recently.
Experts suggest cascading effects from increased wildfires will continue to worsen.
